In order to distinguish and uphold the true meaning of proof and refutation, this treatise is composed.
The many statements of thesis, etc. are able to prove, which is only in accordance with one's own intention;
What is stated for the sake of being established is called a thesis, and the meaning that contradicts it cannot be refuted.

As for the many statements of thesis, etc. are able to prove, because the meaning that is not yet understood by others is debated through the many statements of thesis, reason, and example, these many statements are called able to prove in treatises, etc.

Moreover, when it is said that one statement is able to prove, it is in order to show that it collectively forms the nature of being able to prove. Therefore, it should be understood that if there is any deficiency, it is a fault of being able to prove.
As for the word here, it has the meaning of initiating a discussion, or the meaning of distinguishing and upholding. It is among the theses, etc., and is therefore called here.
As for the word only, it has the meaning of distinguishing.
According to one's own intention shows not caring about the established doctrines, but establishing according to one's own intention.
Pleasure is what is established, meaning not taking pleasure as the nature of what is to be established.
If it were otherwise, what is to be established would be called a thesis, like an inference or an example.
In order to show the faults of establishing a thesis apart from the others, it says the meaning that is contrary to it cannot be refuted.
If the meaning that is not contrary is refuted by the sound of words, like establishing all words are false;
or if it contradicts the meaning of the thesis that was previously established, like the son of a fox establishing sound is permanent;

and moreover, if it is because it is unique, there is no valid cognition, and it is refuted by the meaning that contradicts the word established, like saying the rabbit is not in the moon because it does not exist;

Moreover, regarding existent dharmas, the meaning contradicted by the presently established direct perception and inference established by them is eliminated, just as in the establishment of sound is not audible and pot is permanent, etc.
Those who say that the contradiction between the thesis and reason is called contradiction with the thesis are not at fault in the thesis;

because in this case, establishing sound is permanent, because all are impermanent, is a bad establishment of the dissimilar example by means of the similar example, because it shows that it is not all.

It should be said like this:

However, this inverted statement that all are impermanent is therefore also faulty in this case.
Thus, the thesis and pseudo-thesis have been explained.
The reason and pseudo-reason are mostly the property of the thesis. The characteristics of their distinctions will now be revealed:
The property of the thesis in the similar instance is said to be existent, non-existent, and both;
In the dissimilar instance, there are three each, existent, non-existent, and both.

Now, this is only based on the cause of realization and understanding, so it is only by the power of knowledge that one understands the meaning of what is said, not like a generative cause that gives rise to function.
If that is so, since one takes knowledge as the cause of realization, then speech loses the meaning of being able to establish.

This is also not so, because it causes them to remember what was originally well-established. Therefore, in this case, only taking what is definitely accepted by both parties is considered to be a good explanation.
Thus, if there is something that is not accepted by both parties, it definitely cannot be a property of the thesis, like establishing sound is impermanent because it is seen by the eyes.
Moreover, if the opponent does not accept it, like in the case of the VaibhÄá¹£ika, because of being produced.
Moreover, if there is doubt, like when giving rise to doubt based on smoke, establishing there is fire in the combination of the primary elements, because smoke is present.
Or, if the property of the subject is not established in this case, like establishing the self is all-pervading, because pleasure and so forth arise everywhere.
All such statements, regardless of their type, are not valid forms of proof.
The same should be said about the presence or absence of similar instances, as appropriate.
In the following proofs, only statements that are mutually agreed upon and definite can be called valid forms of proof or refutation.
Ambiguous statements that are not mutually established require further proof.
When establishing a thesis, one should further use other principles as reasons to prove it.
If one directly proves the existence of a dharma or its non-existence, like proving that the supreme is existent because it is seen to have a general category like other things;
or proving that it is non-existent because it cannot be apprehended.
What does this mean?
Here, only the thesis that other things definitely have one cause is established, not the supreme, so there is no fault.
If one establishes it as non-existent, one also provisionally establishes the dharma of non-attainment. Therefore, there is also no error of the existence of a dharma.
If one uses an existent dharma to establish another existent dharma, or to establish its dharma, like using smoke to establish fire, or using fire to establish contact, what is the meaning of this?
In this case, it is not to establish fire and contact as the thesis, but only to establish this corresponding object.
If it were not so, then using smoke to establish fire and using fire to establish contact would constitute using part of the thesis as the reason.
Moreover, in this case, it is not to establish that fire and contact have nature, because it is commonly known that they exist.
Moreover, in this case, the establishment of dharma and existence is based on observation, not on virtue and existence. Therefore, there is no error.
Again, a verse is spoken:

This is said to be an error by the method of thesis and reason, because there is something to be established, the word should is used, and because permanence is established first because of being formless and unobstructed, later only the thesis is established, and the error of the reason is refuted.
If it is established in this way that sound is impermanent, because of the impermanence of what is produced, and because of the non-production of what is permanent, what is this again?
This is a method of analogy.

Because in this case, by combining, the reason of the nature of what is produced is shown. In this way, this sound is definitely produced, not non-produced. This nature of what is produced is definitely the property of the thesis.

Because of this kind of difficulty, if the power of direct perception, inference cannot eliminate its nature.

The second is similar to the fault of the pseudo-unestablished reason.
Because it increases the established by the originally non-existent, and makes the reason for the thesis one fault.

Because in this case one does not wish to establish only the arising of destruction, whether arising or manifesting, all are destroyed, not indeterminate.
The meaning is similar to that of generating difficulties based on the opposite or indeterminacy, thus it resembles an indeterminate reason.

If that which is not generated by diligent effort is established as permanent or impermanent, or if only that which is generated by diligent effort is impermanent and not the other, it can be established as a refutation.

If the establishing reason reaches the established thesis, there would be no distinction and it should not be established, just as there is no difference between the water of a pond and the ocean when they merge.
Moreover, if it is not established, it should not reach the characteristics;
if the established thesis is established, whose reason is this?
If the establishing reason does not reach the established thesis, not reaching and not being a reason would be no different, so it should not be a reason.
This is called the similarity of reaching and not reaching.
Moreover, the unpleasant statement is made in the three periods of time:
If the establishing reason precedes the established thesis, there is nothing yet established, whose reason is this?
If it is said to be after, the established thesis is already accomplished, so what need is there for a reason?
If it is simultaneous, the reason and that which has a reason are both not accomplished, like the two horns of an ox.
This is called the similarity of having no reason.
Among these, the one with the different sequence as before is called the similarity of the deficiency of a reason, because it is said to be simultaneous.
Why is this?
Because it unreasonably denies all causes.
What principle is there here?
Only that which is not yet established is called a reason. Although the characteristics of a reason are appropriate, it is still not called a reason.
What principle is this?
Only that which precedes what is to be established cannot be called a reason and is therefore not a means of valid cognition.
Moreover, there is the fault of self-refutation in this, because it denies what is the same.

In this way, there are similarities to the deficiency of reasons in the case of verbal reasons and wisdom-established reasons. In the case of objective reasons, there are similarities to the non-establishment of reasons, because it unreasonably denies the causes of phenomena.
Like the previous two reasons, in the case of objective reasons, both what is to be established and what is able to establish are not what is to be produced, and therefore do not accord with reason;
If one denies them using correct principles, one can be called a debater.

Many are similar to the thesis means that these similarities of non-statement and so on are mostly similar to the established statement, that is, like the fallacy of an unestablished reason.

Similar to non-arising, before the sound has arisen, it is a superimposition on what is established. The reason for the difficulty is non-existent, so it is called a pseudo-refutation;

Why is this?
Only the general characteristics are taken to establish logical inference, not the specific characteristics.

As for seeking a reason while both agree is called a fallacy similar to arising, it refers to someone raising an objection, saying:
As for the previously established impermanence of pots and so forth, what reason is there to prove it?

As for setting forth a difficulty regarding the example is called a statement similar to a false example, it refers to the fact that the impermanence of pots and so forth is both agreed upon and accomplished, yet saying it is not accomplished is a false example, hence it is called a statement similar to a false example.
Constantly following the nature of impermanence is called a fallacy similar to permanence;
This fallacy of establishing permanence is called a statement similar to a fallacious thesis.
It refers to someone raising an objection, saying:

This is called similar to permanence.
This is a fallacy of the thesis, because it increases the established impermanence.

Because in this case there is no separate real impermanence that relies on this permanence to arise. It is impermanent because it is originally non-existent, temporarily exists, and then returns to non-existence.
